Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an attempt to legitimize government censorship that occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Concerns about the government using corporations to enforce actions it cannot take directly, or being influenced by corporations interested in social engineering.
The legislation is viewed as an overreach of government authority in controlling what people see, hear, or read.
The terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are considered ill-defined, leading to potential confusion and misuse.
The legislation could infringe on freedom of speech and democratic rights to access and share information.
Excluding media and government from the legislation is seen as hypocritical, as they can also spread misinformation.
The legislation could be used to suppress alternative or citizen media and dissenting voices.
Notable Quotes: This proposed legislation appears to be an attempt to legitimise the censorship of Australians that the Government covertly carried out during the Covid drama.

Misinformation cannot be legislated against for the very reason it goes against freedom of speech; our democratic right to access and share information, thoughts, ideas; and the freedom to change our view and/or understanding in light of new information and opinions.
If this legislation goes ahead, the media cannot be excluded.
Limiting this legislation to the digital platforms can easily give a government the means to shut down citizen and independent journalism and shut up dissenting voices.
